Because the pipe burst in the garage to the water heater, it was pretty high up in the garage, and also ran down the wall causing water in the whole main level. Water got all over in my tools and the house smelled pretty bad.

Unfortunately, Lemonade would only provide a small amount of money for all of my tools that got rusted, and failed to provide any money for several things that got damaged due to soaking up water. Because I didn't have a lot of money due to having to move as a result, I had to bring some of that furniture with me to my new place, which I ended up having to get rid of because it brought the bad smell over to my new home. Even though the claim amount they paid was way under the amount of insurance I had, they unfortunately didn't provide enough for me to replace my damaged property. They expected that I only clean the area rugs, which had shrunk and become rippled due to the water, and just generally not looking as crisp as they had, kind of like how old carpet starts to look even if you clean it. Some of the power tools that got wet initially functioned, but after the next use under normal operating conditions they have overheated and generally not provided the strength they used to.

They essentially asserted that a whole lot of my stuff that got wet and damaged wasn't in need of replacement because it was only cosmetic or still was operational based on just plugging it in and turning it on. Unfortunately, the water damage resulted had lasting effects that made the property unusable for it's intended purpose. Much like a car that gets flooded can work, there are a whole bunch of problems with them when you actually try to use them normally, which is why insurances pay to replace them and consumers are cautioned against purchasing cars that have been subject to flooding.

text:
I purchased homeowner's insurance from Lemonade two years ago when I bought my house. The buying process went smoothly and the people I spoke with were friendly and accommodating.  Anytime thereafter, if I had a question or concern, I was always happy with the customer service I received. 

Then, out of nowhere this past summer, I received an email from Lemonade requesting pictures of my roof and of the sticker on my water heater (to establish its age), making it clear that the renewal of my homeowner’s policy was contingent upon receipt of these pictures. After providing what was asked for, I received notice that Lemonade would not be renewing my policy stating: “Our guidelines specify that we aren’t able to cover homes with water heaters outside of their usable lifespan or a roof condition that does not meet our standards of maintenance.” 

Based on pictures only, they determined that my roof did not meet their standards – the same roof that two years prior was just fine (Note: the single layer of shingles on my roof received a good grade and was described as being “less than half of their maximum life expectancy” by the home inspector who examined them during the buying process). Question. Wouldn’t something deemed “outside of [its] usable lifespan” be something that is no longer usable; as in it no longer works? My water heater, which again was just fine 24 months ago, was suddenly an issue big enough to warrant non-renewal of my insurance policy unless replaced. Who replaces a water heater, or something like that, based solely on its estimated life expectancy? Nobody does! When it starts acting up or stops working, that’s when it gets replaced. Mine works fine, shows no signs of wear or rust or any soon-to-fail red flags. And as I told the agent at Lemonade, even if it were to fail - water pouring out all over - it is in a section of my basement that purposefully has a drain directly next to it should such a disaster happen. Regardless, Lemonade insisted that these two critical issues were of such magnitude as to warrant severing ties with me. 

Something seemed off; something still does. I asked several homeowner friends if they’d ever experienced or heard of anything similar and nobody had, and everyone thought it was really odd. I even ran the scenario by insurance agents I spoke with while getting quotes for a new policy and they seemed genuinely confused by it as well. 

It initially seemed like Lemonade had a good thing going as a relative newcomer in the insurance world but, their new spin on an old model doesn’t seem to be all that it was hoped to be. It’s been said, when life gives you lemons, make lemonade. In this case, however, I’m just going to grab the vodka and the sugar and make lemon drops.

We have enjoyed lemonade for the ease of use ... until we had to use it beyond the app. The process of submitting a claim start to finish, was easy and then became awful in terms of clarity, communication, and professionalism.  

It's been very disappointing and we are currently planning to end our coverage in the coming months!

Separately - the app has pretty regular issues with the gps/location and we often got emails saying our car insurance policy would be terminated if we did not turn our gps/location back on so the app could track our driving. We always had it on. We always had to email them and ask for support on this. We never learned why it kept happening and just had to deal with the nuisance.

Update: After researching new insurance companies, we learned that lemonade rep erroneously submitted a claim on our account that we called them about, but ultimately decided not to submit the claim. text:
Initially I liked this company's pet insurance but between them not 'fully' paying for things because of 'loopholes' and continued policy increases (2023 increased by 29% from 2022) it makes more sense to just put away money into a separate account.

Submissions are all via the app which is okay, however, the first time I needed to file a claim it took weeks to get reimbursed.  They then try to make you jump through hoops to get a copy of the Vet 'notes' from the chart but I always not tell them that 'they can call and get it themselves'.  

They don't cover the initial pet exam fee which is similar to you paying your 'copayment' if you go to a doctor, however, what they fail to tell you is that vets all charge this different and/or can combine charges so while it 'may' partially be an exam fee it often times can be a fee that is both an exam fee but something is also performed.  For example, they did not reimburse when I brought my dog BACK to the vet to get stitches out simply because the vet does charge a 'Office Visit - level 2' but it includes the cost of removing sutures which is a line item below it, but it says the cost is 'included' in the office visit charge.  So they refuse to even consider the fact that the office visit was to remove sutures and not for an exam.  So you end up getting NOTHING back!

I can give many examples like this, they simply look for loopholes to NOT give you money back and their customer service is all online which means no one is really answering your complaints.

I would switch companies but unfortunately I have this policy for 2 dogs and both have had 'some' claims in 2022 so anything related in the future would be declined be a different company.

If I had to do pet insurance ALL over again, I would simply put away $100/pet into a savings account per month and you'd by far be better of doing that than dealing with this awful pet insurance companies.

text: BEWARE. I have had Lemonade for the past few years, and used to rave about them. I heard they are losing money and raising rates so possibly this is why they are changing, but how did they donate so much in unused payouts last year? (Which was one of the features I loved) Recently, it seems since Covid, things have changed. I never filed a claim, nor for years before I was with Lemonade, and always paid on time. They seemed so nice - maybe too nice? But then in late Spring of 2022 I was working less due to Covid and when I went into my Lemonade account, I got a message saying "You can take up to 60 days to pay your premium" now because of Covid, and "We also extended our grace period." I thought "these people are amazing!" Well, I didn't use the 60 days, but I felt no pressure and did pay the day after and a couple days after my normal due date knowing I had more time for a few months. I took screenshots of Lemonade's messages and kept copies of the emails I received, so I have proof. Well, I just got a notice that they have decided to not renew my policy because of "uneven payments" - I contacted them, and apparently their management was not talking with their underwriters because the rude gentlemen in the underwriting department I spoke with insisted that you can't be late at all, even when I showed them proof that Lemonade offered people more time. They had no interest in hearing it or discussing it. This "uneven payments" was the only reason they gave. I never filed any claims and never was late (before what they now call late because it barely went past the normal due date by a couple days, which they offered and encouraged way more than that). So, Lemonade basically told people they had extended their grace period and had 60 days to pay when they really didn't. I would have been much more vigilant if I hadn't depended on that offer they gave me. I imagine other people will find out they were duped and get dropped, as well, which makes it harder to get insurance from another provider. I will be contacting the state insurance regulators to report my experience with Lemonade's very misleading and possibly illegal behavior. You shouldn't be able to renege and penalize people for simply taking advantage of an offer you chose to make. Don't trust them - they aren't good for their word. They're clearly mismanaged. And if you ever have an emergency where you need to file a claim, I wouldn't be surprised if they blame you and bail.
title: BEWARE misleading, mismanaged, not reliable

text:
Honest Lemonade Pet Insurance Review

I want to start off by saying Vanessa was AMAZING and so SWEET she handled my claim and did everything she could to try and help me. 

However, I would think twice before getting pet insurance or specifically upgrading to the Preventive Care Package with Lemonade.

I LOVED Lemonade as a company! I have my home owners insurance through them and HAD my pet insurance through them. I loved how easy the app was! 

Before insurance started my dog Paxton had his physical exam and lemonade got all his records and everything seemed fine and was going smoothly. The I preventive care package includes shots, heart worm medications, one yearly dental cleaning, and blood work. So of course when I saw the dental cleaning coverage I was sold!! That is the most expensive part about preventive care so of course I would do it. 

Well, I scheduled his dental consultation and sent in the receipt and it took 2 full months for them to look over the dental cleaning claim. I thought that was a long time just for a dental cleaning. Well while the dental cleaning was being preformed the vet called me and said he had one infected tooth and it would be $65 to remove it and they would just pull it out during his routine dental cleaning so he wouldn't have to have anesthesia twice. I agreed to that. 

Lemonade Contacted me saying they will not be able to cover the visit because he had Periodontal Disease…. So I said okay well I don’t mind paying full for the tooth  being pulled but you are still going to cover the dental cleaning? They said they are going to DENY the dental cleaning and I will have to pay in full. ($400) 

But when I asked even if he didn’t have periodontal disease he would still need a dental cleaning once a year right? Because that is what the vet recommends for all dogs? They said I understand what you are saying. So what I got from that is that a teeth cleaning should be routine once a year EVEN if the dog doesn’t have periodontal disease. I felt mislead because I was never told what would not be covered based on his record. How would I know a routine dental cleaning wouldn’t be covered!? It’s ROUTINE for every dog even if they have no issues!! I completely understand paying for the tooth being pulled because that is from the Periodontal Disease so I was happy to pay for that but to pay in full for the routine once a year dental cleaning!?! Even though my policy INCLUDES one routine yearly dental cleaning. 

That was a 🚩 for me and I decided to cancel and share my experience so someone else will not be mislead and pay for something that says COVERED when it is NOT. 

I would request after you submit the records of your pet for them to send you a list of what IS actually covered and what is NOT covered. That way there won’t be ANY gray area and it will just be black and white like it should be! I recommended Lemonade to everyone I knew!! Not anymore!! Hopefully this will help the company be more clear to their customers. Most of us aren’t Veterinarians or familiar enough to know what’s covered based on a pet exam. 

I would look into ManyPets for pet insurance. I have friends who use them and said they are great and cover dental cleaning even if he the dog has periodontal disease because it’s a ROUTINE procedure that every dog is recommended to get yearly.

I finally got a supervisor by request... still only through email, who expanded on Lemonade's claims process, pretty much stating it is the way it is and then encouraging me to cancel, confirming it being impossible to reach somebody, being unable to process a claim with a licensed agent, the disinterest in the emergency situations of their customers, the likelihood a claim would be denied anyway, the reimbursement nature of the policy, the sketchy fine print, all of it. I went through with the cancel.  I looked further at the reviews on the app store and BBB and it is a very clear consensus that this company is shady and will go above and beyond to NOT protect you, pets, or property in a time of need. I felt like I was the one being punished for my neighbor's negligent cooking fire, which could have killed me (I literally got trapped on the fourth floor of a burning building) and made all my belongings reek.
